1. The Scottish Sea Bird Centre

Just 30 minutes from Edinburgh by train, the seaside town of North Berwick has been called "the Biarritz of the North" (perhaps by someone with a dry sense of humour). It is home to the Bass Rock, an extinct volcano described by Sir David Attenborough, a man who knows about such things, as "one of the wildlife wonders of the world" because of its rock gannet colony. You can take boat trips to the Rock.

· Scottish Seabird Centre; +44 (0)1620 890 202. Summer opening times (April to Sept) Monday to Sunday, 10am-6pm. Check website for winter opening times. Adult £7.95 (£5.95 concessions), child £4.50

2. Inchcolm Island

A sliver of land in the middle of the Firth of Forth, Inchcolm Island has been of strategic importance since Roman times right up until the second world war, when it was fortified in the event of an attack on Edinburgh. Visited by St Columba in the sixth century, it's now home to an impressive abbey – hence it is known as the Iona of the east. Great views of Edinburgh from the beach.

· Catch the Maid of Forth ferry from South Queensferry. The trips are three hours in duration, with one and a half hours on shore. Adult £10, child £3.50

3. Hopetoun House

Set in 150 acres of parkland and woodland, with its own deer park, Hopetoun House is one of the finest examples of Georgian architecture in the UK. As well as the surroundings, including views of the Forth and the magnificence of the house itself, there's a smashing tearoom.

· Hopetoun House, South Queensferry; +44 (0)131 331 2451. Open daily from: Friday March 21 to Sunday Sept 28 2008, 10.30am-5pm (last entry 4pm). Adult £8 (concessions £7), child (age 5-16) £4.25

4. Linlithgow Palace

Perched beside a lovely loch and beside the 15th-century St Michael's Church (which is topped with a terribly modern steeple), Linlithgow Palace was where Mary Queen of Scots was born in 1542. Two hundred years later, it was visited by Bonnie Prince Charlie and was mostly destroyed in 1746 by the Duke of Cumberland's advancing army.

· Linlithgow Palace, Linlithgow, +44 (0)1506 842 896. Open daily from 9.30am-5.30pm (March 21 to Sept 30 2008) and 9.30am-4.30pm (Oct 1- March 31 2009). Adult £5.20 (concession £4.20), child £2.60

5. Gullane

Blessed with both beaches and golf courses, there are plenty of wonderful walks to be had in Gullane, a lovely town to the east of Edinburgh along the A198. Probably the finest beach is Gullane Bents, which is a rather lovely place to picnic.

· Gullane, East Lothian

6. Traquair Castle, Innerleithen

Though there's plenty to recommend Traquair Castle – a cute museum, Mary Queen of Scots memorabilia, a brewery in the grounds – the biggest thrill to be had in this stately home 29 miles from Edinburgh is wandering around the maze, planted in 1981, which covers an acre and a half and is a quarter of a mile from edge to centre. It's a challenge best not undertaken after a visit to the brewery.

· Traquair Castle; 44 (0)1896 830323. Open March, April, May and Sept, 12pm–5pm, June to Aug, 10.30am–5pm, Oct to Nov, 11am-3pm. Entry to house and grounds: Adult £6.50, child £3.50

7. Shark diving in Fife

You don't have to go as far as South Africa to get your Jaws experience. Shark diving in Fife's Deep Sea World involves jumping in an aquarium rather than the big blue and there are no Great Whites; however, this means you won't have suffer the North Sea's biting temperatures and, as the resident Sand Tiger sharks aren't considered dangerous to humans, no protective cages are needed. To get there, just board a train over the Forth Bridge to North Queensferry from Waverley or Haymarket in Edinburgh city centre (15 mins).

· deepseaworld.com; +44 (0)1383 411 880. The shark dive experience costs £155. There's also a special children's course costing £35

8. Beecraigs Country Park

Among other things in the 913 acres of the park, which sits in the Bathgate Hills near Linlithgow, you'll find a deerpark, a saw mill, a fishery and facilities for outdoor pursuits, such as archery, canoeing, climbing and orienteering. Alternatively, you could just take a picnic and relish the countryside instead.

· Beecraigs Country Park, West Lothian, EH49 6PL; beecraigs.com; +44 (0)1506 844516

9. Musselburgh

Dubbed "the honest toun", Musselburgh is perched on the coastal outskirts of Edinburgh and is blessed, not just with picturesque scenery, a dandy beach and good travel links to the city centre, but also a racecourse and – most important of all - one of Scotland's most famous ice cream parlours – S Luca. Founded in the town in 1908, it's one of many established in the country by Italian immigrants and, to this day, it remains a family business.

10. Glasgow

Sacrilegious though it sounds, a visit to Edinburgh's grittier sister city takes only 50 minutes by train and counts, during festival time anyway, as an oasis of calm with nary a stilt walker, desperate student theatre company or mime artist to be seen. Although there may be the occasional busker on Buchanan Street, known for its shopping, or in the café-dotted streets of the Merchant City, Glasgow could nevertheless provide welcome respite from the crowds of Edinburgh. Providing you dodge the radges, drunks and neds.

"We will never share our homeland and Jerusalem with anyone else." So said Nadia Matar, de facto shepherd of her flock of acolytes as they marched around the walls of Jerusalem's Old City on Saturday night to commemorate Tisha Ba'av, the saddest day in the Jewish calendar.

Orthodox Jews traditionally mark the occasion by adopting an air of mourning, reading the Book of Lamentations, fasting and quietly remembering all of the tragedies that have befallen the Jewish people throughout history. However, in the twisted world of Matar and her supporters, the best way to deal with the pain of our historical suffering is to take out our anger on others, namely the Palestinians, in an annual show of force infused with hardline nationalism.

Several hundred marchers gathered in the courtyard of the Jerusalem Municipality headquarters on the edge of the Old City, eagerly awaiting Nadia's orders to begin their parade. Despite the unabashedly sectarian nature of the march – "The land of Israel for the people of Israel" was emblazoned across dozens of flags and banners – the authorities seemingly had no issue with the event taking place. Neither, apparently, did any opposition group – as I reported last year, the demonstration goes unchallenged by counter-protest.

The authorities had even cleared the streets of Palestinians, laying on scores of heavily armed policemen to protect the marchers as they strode defiantly into the heart of East Jerusalem. No matter to them the message of hate being preached by Matar over the microphone; nor the parrot-like cries of her disciples as they repeatedly jeered "Jerusalem is ours" to the silent Palestinians watching from behind the police lines.

The authorities decided, in their wisdom, to turn a similarly blind eye to the incitement spouted by the raft of speakers who addressed the adoring crowd in front of the aptly-named Lion's Gate. Roaring their righteous anger and whipping the crowd into a nationalistic fervour, they assured their audience that it was the Jews' divine right to take whatever they wanted from whoever they wanted, in order to hasten the coming of the Messiah and the building of the Third Temple. "It's all ours," one man proclaimed into the microphone, to thunderous applause, "so why should we be scared to say it?"

When the Second Temple was razed by the Romans, the prophet Jeremiah lamented the fall of Jerusalem, describing the defeated city as "destroyed, and without inhabitants". The triumph of having retaken Jerusalem by force almost 2,000 years later is, to many orthodox Jews, reason not to fast on Tisha Ba'av, since the city is no longer in the ruinous state as described by Jeremiah – at least, not from a Jewish perspective.

To Nadia Matar, as well as those trailing reverentially in her wake around the Old City walls, the Jewish perspective is the only one that matters, hence her complete inability to see how the Jews' tortured history is repeating itself today, albeit in mirror-image form. The parallels between Palestinian residents of Jerusalem being discriminated against and persecuted by the Israeli authorities and the ignominy suffered by Jews throughout the ages are as clear as day, yet don't make the slightest impression on those for whom Jewish dominion over Greater Israel is everything.

When Nadia Matar boasted into the camera that "we won't share our homeland and Jerusalem with anyone else", she epitomised all that is so tragic about religious Zionism, the bastard child born of Judaism's illicit union with rampant nationalism. Instead of using the occasion of Tisha Ba'av for quiet contemplation and solemn reflection on the universal aspect of suffering, those marching round Jerusalem loudly declared their intent to focus simply on reminding the world that the Jews are back, and woe betide anyone who stands in their way.

That alone should be reason to continue mourning the fate of the Jewish people, despite our having returned to our ancestral home and having dominion over Jerusalem once more. We might think we've been freed from the yoke of oppression, but in truth it's still with us; it just happens that we've shackled it to someone else's necks, rather than they to ours.

In a sermon in London yesterday, Rabbi Michael Pollak asked how – given that Anglo Jewry enjoys a richer, more pampered lifestyle than any other Jewish community throughout history – Jews could truly understand what suffering feels like. His answer was that one way modern Jews can discover the pain of aveilut (mourning) is through empathising with the suffering of others, past and present, Jewish and non-Jewish.

Part of the Jewish experience has been, sadly, to suffer great losses and hardships throughout the ages, but one positive aspect of such anguish is that we are better equipped to identify with others in the same boat; be they fleeing villagers in Gori, starving children in Harare, or impoverished residents of refugee camps trapped behind Israel's separation wall. Jewish philanthropy has saved countless lives around the world, and improved the lot of innumerable others, but when it comes to Israel, for many Jews there remains an insurmountable blind spot.

Until the perspective of Nadia Matar and the other vanguards of religious Zionism changes for the better, there is little hope for those on the receiving end of their actions. And that is a modern-day calamity to befall the Jewish people, and one well worth mourning on such a tragic date in our calendar.

With Gordon Brown still on holiday in Scotland, David Cameron is doing his best to seize the initiative.

He was on the World at One yesterday with some very robust, gung-ho language about Russia, and he managed to ensure that when Brown's own statement on the crisis was released a couple of hours later, it sounded rather lame. (Although Cameron has the luxury of not having to deal with these people at the moment and, like all western politicians talking tough, he was very vague as to what sanctions he would actually use against the Russians in practice.)

He will probably get asked about that this morning.

It's started. Cameron is making a statement about the Georgian conflict. He says it looks as if Russia is trying to topple the Georgian regime, and as if it is trying to send a message to Ukraine and the central Asian states to the effect that they cannot afford to defy Moscow.

He says the government must take various measures. Has the government summoned the Russian ambassador? Has the government proposed an urgent meeting of Nato foreign ministers? Is the government considering visa changes for Russian citizens? Is it considering calling for Russia to be suspended from the G8?

He says that if Russia is allowed to get away with this, they will try similar tactics against other countries.

He repeats the line he used yesterday: "The only language bullies understand is when you face up to them."

He is moving on to domestic concerns, and the economy.

Today's inflation figures are very worrying for people trying to make ends meet, he says. But the government cannot wave a magic wand.

On fuel prices, the Tories are considering flexible duty rates.

On business, the Tories are looking at changes to insolvency laws.

10.30am

The government's decision to brief about the possibility of a stamp duty holiday was "reckless". It has frozen up the housing market.

Cameron says he will be meeting the National Association of Estate Agents this afternoon. The association has asked three times to meet the chancellor, Alistair Darling, but he has refused to see them.

The Conservatives are holding a seminar on housing. It will consider policies to free up the market, policies to prevent people having their homes prepossessed and measures that could stop the problem recurring. But the party won't be announcing policies.

Then he invites questions.

Stamp duty

Vicky Young from the BBC asks if Cameron thinks abolishing stamp duty for first-time buyers (the Tory policy) is responsible at a time when young people should not be encouraged to buy into the housing market.

Cameron does not accept this. He says stamp duty is an issue for first-time buyers. But his plan will not rescue the housing market on its own.

Russia

Niall Patterson from Sky News asks if Cameron is accusing the government of inaction.

Cameron says the government must engage with the issues. There are a series of things the government could do that would send "a very clear message" that what the Russians did was unacceptable.

Because the Georgian strategy was "misguided", some people are unclear as to who is to blame.

But Cameron says he is clear that Russia is in the wrong.

The next election

Graeme Wilson from the Sun asks if Cameron agrees with William Hague when he said last week that the Tories were the "likely winners" of the next election.

Cameron says he does not use those words. "There is no complacency". There is a "huge difference" between people saying they want another government and people actually voting for his party at a general election.

The Tories still have a "long way to go". There will be "no smugness, no complacency".

10.35am

Green taxes/the Glasgow East "fat" speech/Preparing for government

James Lyons from the Mirror asks about three question in one go. It's probably a record.

Asked about the session at the autumn conference called "preparing for government", Cameron says that is sensible planning. He says there was a session at the spring conference on preparing for government too. It does not mean he's being complacent.

On green taxes, he says green taxes will be offset by tax cuts elsewhere.

On the Glasgow speech, in which he said sometimes people were to blame for being fat, he says he stands by it.

Lyons asked if he had discussed it with Eric Pickles (the local government spokesman, who is on the large side). Cameron does not comment on Pckles's girth directly, but he says that all members of the shadow cabinet supported it.

Georgia/David Miliband

Michael White from the Guardian asks about Georgia, and also whether Cameron agrees with Hague's verdict in the interview last week that David Miliband is a bit of a "geek".

Cameron won't be drawn on Miliband. He claims not to know very much about who is or isn't a geek.

On Georgia, he says it would be "very dangerous" to allow Russia to intervene in Georgia because of the interests of Russians living in South Ossetia.

Mike says the Russians could be seen as having a legitimate interest in what happens in South Ossetia. (I haven't really done justice to his point, but he blogged on this yesterday.)

Cameron says there is a difference between having a legitimate interest and invading.

Labour leadership

Would Cameron like to see Gordon Brown stay in post?

Cameron says he has always used the line that it is hard enough to run your own party, without trying to talk about what should be happening in others. He says he has "no idea" what will happen within Labour

Repossessions

Jean Eaglesham from the FT asks if Cameron is in favour of statutory measures to prevent unnecessary home repossessions.

Cameron says that is exactly the kind of issue that the party will be discussing at its housing seminar today.

10.45am

We're going to have to leave it there, I'm afraid, because I'm monitoring it from the TV and the live broadcasts have all dried up.

Summary

Russia: More tough talk about Moscow. Cameron even answered my point about "what would he do?" with a short list of measures the government could be implementing, or at least considering. His words do leave the official Foreign Office/Downing Street response looking a bit feeble.

In the scheme of things this probably did not amount to very much - comments that Brown and Cameron issued yesterday did not get much coverage in the papers today, as far as I could see - but it must be reassuring for the Tories to "beat" the government within the news cycle.

Housing: Again, Cameron scored another, easy hit. He criticised the government for damaging the housing market by briefing newspapers last week about the possibility of a stamp duty holiday and he revealed that the Tories are holding a seminar on the subject today. He has not got any policies to announce, but at least the Tories look concerned.

The Labour leadership situation: It's easy to imagine Cameron having something to say about this. He could have taunted Miliband for not standing against Brown, or praised him lavishly. But he chose to stay out of it.

That sun tan: Did you see it? I'm not quite sure how anyone gets a tan that good from a fortnight in Devon, but he certainly looks like a man who's had a good holiday.

A radio station banned by the Chinese authorities has filed a formal complaint with the International Olympic Committee after the Beijing organising committee (Bocog) failed to issue one of its correspondents with media accreditation.

Dhondup Gonsar, who is of Tibetan descent and broadcasts in the Tibetan language on Radio Free Asia (RFA), is yet to receive his accreditation documents despite his application being approved by the IOC.

The incident has undermined IOC claims that journalists would have freedom to report during these games. Under Beijing's Olympic contract with the IOC all accredited persons should be granted access to the country.

Bocog is responsible for producing the actual accreditation document, which doubles as a visa. Yesterday Bocog said that Gonsar's documents remained "in process" and that a decision was "pending".

IOC spokeswoman Giselle Davies said the matter had been "flagged" with Bocog but could not say when or if the documents would be issued.

RFA, a non profit-making organisation sponsored by the US Congress, broadcasts within China via shortwave and on the internet, though its website is usually blocked by the authorities. It is critical of the Beijing regime and those in other undemocratic Asian states.

Jill Ku Martin, chief correspondent of RFA's Mandarin service, said today she suspected her colleague had been barred because of his Tibetan nationality. "We can only speculate as to why it is happening but he is of Tibetan descent and broadcasts in the Tibetan language," she said.
